Week 2 Lecture Notes
Group 3

4.1 Divisibility and Modular Arithmetic

Definition: Divides

Let a, b $\in \mathbb{Z}$. We say a divides b. denoted, a|b if $\exists k\in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $b = a \cdot k$ >e.g. $\quad \quad$ 3|9 because 9 = 3 $\cdot$ 3 $\quad \quad$ 2$\nmid$9 because $\nexists k$ such that 9 = 2 $\cdot$ $k$ ##### Example 1 Let n, d $\in \mathbb{Z}$ such that n $\geq$ d. How many positive integers not exceeding n, are divisible by d? $$n = 9$$ $$d = 6$$ $$I = \{1,2,\ldots, 9\}$$ **Answer:** 6 in $I$ is the only number divisible by 6
6$k$, $k \in \mathbb{Z}$ Goal: 6$k \leq$ 9 for which values of k? $\Rightarrow$ $k \leq \frac{\mathrm 9}{\mathrm 6}$ $\Rightarrow$ $k \leq $ 1 $\Rightarrow$ $k$ = ${\color{red}1}$, only one that satisfies. >e.g. $$n = 9$$ $$d = 6$$ All numbers divisible by 2 have the form
2$k$, $k \in \mathbb{Z}$
$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad$Restriction:
$2k \leq 9$ $k \leq \frac{\mathrm 9}{\mathrm 2}$ $ k \leq 4$ $\Rightarrow k = {\color{red}1}$ or ${\color{red}2}$ or ${\color{red}3}$ or ${\color{red}4}$
##### For general $n$ and $d$, all numbers divisible by $d$ have the form ### $$d \cdot k \quad\quad\quad k \in \mathbb{Z}$$ $\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad \quad$$\quad$Restriction:
$dk \leq n$ $\Rightarrow k \leq \frac{\mathrm n}{\mathrm d}$ $range: 1,2 \ldots \lfloor \frac{\mathrm n}{\mathrm d} \rfloor$ $\lfloor \frac{\mathrm n}{\mathrm d} \rfloor$ number of integers divisible by d in range 1 to n.
$\quad$ ### Theorem
**Let a, b, c $\in\mathbb{Z}$, where a $\neq$ 0.** **Then**
1. if **a | b** and **a |c**, then **a | (b + c)**
2. if **a | b**, then **a | bc**, **$\forall c \in \mathbb{Z} $**
3. if **a | b** and **b | c**, then **a | c** >e.g. >1. if 3 | 9 and 3 | 6, then 3 | (6 + 9) >2. if 3 | 9 and 3 | (9 $\cdot$ 2) >3. if 3 | 9 and 3 | 18 then 3 | 18 #### Proof
1. a | b $\rightarrow \exists k \in \mathbb{Z}$ $\quad$ b = a $\cdot$ k by definition a | c $\rightarrow \exists q \in \mathbb{Z}$ $\quad$ c = a $\cdot$ q by definition $\quad$ $\Rightarrow b + c = a \cdot k + a \cdot q$ $\quad b + c = a \cdot (k + q)$ $\quad\quad\quad\quad b + c = a \cdot (p) \quad\quad\quad p\in\mathbb{Z}$ $\Rightarrow$ a | (b + c) $\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \blacksquare$ $\quad$
2. a | b $\rightarrow \exists k \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad$ b $=$ a $\cdot$ k $\quad\quad\quad\quad$ $b \cdot c = a \cdot k \cdot c \quad \forall c \in \mathbb{Z}$ $\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad = a \cdot p \quad\quad p \in \mathbb{Z} \quad p = kc$ $\Rightarrow$ a | bc $\quad\quad\quad$ $\quad\quad\quad\quad \blacksquare$ $\quad$
3. a | b $\rightarrow \exists k \in \mathbb{Z}$ $\quad$ b = a $\cdot$ k a | c $\rightarrow \exists q \in \mathbb{Z}$ $\quad$ c = b $\cdot$ q $\quad$ $\Rightarrow c = a \cdot k \cdot q$ $\quad c = a \cdot p$ $\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad c = a \cdot p \quad\quad\quad p\in\mathbb{Z}$ $\Rightarrow$ a | c $\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \blacksquare$ $\quad$ ___ #### Division Algorithm $$\sqrt[3]{5} = 1{}^2/_3 $$ $$Answer: 5 = 3 \cdot 1 + 2$$ ### Theorem
**Let a, d $\in\mathbb{Z^+}$.** **Then $\exists ! q,r \in \mathbb{Z}$** **a = d $\cdot$ q + r $\quad $where r $\geq$ 0** ``` a = divisor q = quotient r = remainder ``` >e.g. >$\quad\quad 9 \div 3 \quad\quad $ remainder = 0 >$\quad\quad 9 \div 4 \quad\quad $ remainder $\neq$ 0 #### Proof $$1. \quad d | a$$ $$\exists k \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad a = d \cdot k + 0$$ $$a = d \cdot k + r \quad where\space r = 0 $$ $\quad$ $$ 2. \quad d \nmid a$$ $$\exists r \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad d | a - r$$ $$\exists q \in \mathbb{Z} \quad\quad a - r = d \cdot q$$ $$a = d \cdot q + r \quad $$ >e.g. $\quad$$\quad$ 4 $\nmid$ 9 $\quad$$\quad 4 | 9 - 1 \Rightarrow 9 - 1 = 4 \cdot 2 $ $\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad \Rightarrow 9 = 4 \cdot 2 + 1$ $\quad$ $\quad$ ___ Definition: ***Mod***
Let $ a = d \cdot q + r \quad$ Then we say $a \mod d = r $ when a divided by d results in remainder r. ##### Example 2 ###### Which of the quotient and remainder when -11 is divided by 3? ``` i) 101 mod 2 = 11 False r = 11 > d = 2 ii) 101 mod 11 = 2 True 101 = 11 * 9 + 2 d>r iii) 11 mod 2 = 101 False r = 101 > d = 2 iv) 101 mod 2 = 1 True 101 = 2 * 50 + 1 d>r ``` ##### Example 3 ###### What are the quotient and remainder when -11 is divided by 3? ``` -11 = 3 * -4 + 1 q = -4 r = 1 ``` ___ Definition: ***Div***
Let a = dq + r $\quad$ Then we say a div d = q When a divided by d has quotient q
##### Example 4 ###### what is -11 div 3 ? ``` -4 ``` ___ ## Modular Arithmetic Definition: ***Congruence Module m***
Let a,b $\in \mathbb{Z}$ we say a is congruent to b module m, denoted $ a \equiv b \left( \mod m \right) $ if $\exists k \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that a - b = m $\cdot$ k >i.e. $\quad$ m | a - b $\quad$ ##### *Note a mod d = r is NOT the same as a $\equiv$ b (mod m) * a mod d = r is a **function** * a $\equiv$ b (mod) m is a **relation** ``` Recall: A = {1, 2, 3} B = {a, b, c} A relation: R ≤ A * B {(1,a), (1,b), (1,c)} A function adds the restriction that every input must have ONLY ONE output. ``` >e.g. $\quad\quad 4 \equiv 1 (\mod 3) $ because $3 | (4-1)$ $\quad\quad 4 \equiv 3 (\mod 1) $ because $1 | (4-3)$ $\quad\quad 5 \equiv 3 (\mod 2) $ because $2 | (5-3)$ $\quad\quad 5 \equiv 1 (\mod 2)$ because $2 | (5-1)$ ``` Notice 5 ≡ 3 and 5 ≡ 1 module 2, hence not a function. R: Relation that pairs congruent integers module 2 = {(5,3), (5,1)...} F: Function = {(a,r) | a mod d = r} consider a = 5, d = 4 F = {(5,r) | r = 5 mod 4} = {(5,1)} f(a,d) = r ``` ##### Example 5 ###### Determine which of the following are true? ``` i) 7 ≡ 3 (mod 4) True 4 | (7 - 3) ii) 7 ≡ 3 = 4 False 7 ÷ 3, remainder is 1 iii) 15 ≡ 3 (mod 5) False 5 ∤ (15 - 3) iv) 15 ≡ 5 (mod 2) True 2 | (15 - 5) ``` ### Theorem
Let $m \in \mathbb{Z^+} \quad$ if $\quad a \equiv b (\mod m)$ and $c \equiv d (\mod m)$ i) $\quad a + c \equiv b + d ( \mod m)$ ii) $\quad\quad\quad ac \equiv bd ( \mod m)$ #### Proof
$a + c = mk + b + mq + d$ $a + c = m(k + q) + (b + d)$ $a + c = ml + (b + d)$ $(a + c) - (b + d) = ml$ $A - B = ml$ $A \equiv B (\mod m)$ $a + c = (b + d)(\mod m)$ #### Corollary ``` a + b (mod m) = [(a mod m) + (b mod m)] mod m ab (mod m) = [(a mod m)(b mod m)] mod m ``` ___ ## Arithmetic Modulo m Definition: ***$\mathbb{Z}_m = \{0,1, \ldots, m-1\}$*** Operation on $\mathbb{Z}_m$ * $a +_m b = (a + b) \mod m$ * $a \cdot_m b= (a \cdot b) \mod m$ >Ex: Let m = 11 Find
$i) 7+_m9=(7+9) \mod 11 \rightarrow 16 \mod 11 = 5$ $ii) 7\cdot_m9=(7\cdot9) \mod 11 \rightarrow 63 \mod 11 = 8$ $\quad$ $\quad$ $\quad$ $\quad$ $\quad$ $\quad$ $\quad$ ___ ***End of 1/31/2017 Lecture Note*** $\mathit{Contributor: Zhipeng Mei}$ $\mathit{Team: Zhipeng Mei, Zhongyu Wang, Patrapee Pongtana}$ ###### Link: [Original Markdown file KaTeX supported](https://github.com/AnimeMei/Markdown-Files/tree/master/CECS%20229%20Lecture%20Notes)
